description: Seek quotes on Neuralink’s brain-computer interfaces, weighing cognitive liberation (e.g., enhanced learning, disability mitigation) against dependency risks (e.g., tech reliance, privacy loss). quotes.source: Superintelligence: Paths, Dangers, Strategies
quotes.author: Nick Bostrom
quotes.verification_info: Chapter 13, 'The Strategic Picture', page 260 of the Oxford University Press, 2014 hardcover edition. Verifiable with book copy or Google Books preview.

quotes.quote: The main products of the twenty-first-century economy will not be textiles, vehicles and weapons, but bodies, brains and minds. And the gap between those who know how to engineer bodies and brains and those who do not will be far bigger than the gap between rich and poor in the twentieth century.
quotes.source: Homo Deus: A Brief History of Tomorrow
quotes.author: Yuval Noah Harari
quotes.verification_info: Part III, 'Homo Deus', Chapter 8, 'The Time Bomb in the Laboratory', page 318 of the Harper Perennial 2017 paperback edition. Verifiable with book copy or extensive previews.

quotes.quote: Big Data is a new, highly efficient instrument of psychopolitics. It makes it possible to gain comprehensive knowledge of the dynamics of communication that are taking place within society – and to influence individuals on a pre-reflexive level.
quotes.source: Psychopolitics: Neoliberalism and New Technologies of Power
quotes.author: Byung-Chul Han
quotes.verification_info: Chapter 'Big Data', page 23 of the Verso Books, 2017 English translation by Erik Butler. Verifiable with book copy or Google Books preview.

quotes.quote: Technopoly is a state of culture. It is also a state of mind. It consists in the deification of technology, which means that the culture seeks its authorization in technology, finds its satisfactions in technology, and takes its orders from technology.
quotes.source: Technopoly: The Surrender of Culture to Technology
quotes.author: Neil Postman
quotes.verification_info: Page 71 of the 1993 Vintage Books edition. Verified via Google Books.

quotes.quote: The quest for 'liberation' through technology often masks a deeper impulse towards control and optimization, where human messiness is seen as a problem to be solved, rather than a condition to be embraced.
quotes.source: To Save Everything, Click Here: The Folly of Technological Solutionism
quotes.author: Evgeny Morozov
quotes.verification_info: Page xiv (Introduction) of the 2013 Allen Lane / PublicAffairs edition. Verified via Google Books.

quotes.quote: Technology, in its prevailing pattern, procures goods as commodities. A commodity is a good that has been stripped of its context of engagement with a person's body and mind and with a binding social setting.
quotes.source: Technology and the Character of Contemporary Life: A Philosophical Inquiry
quotes.author: Albert Borgmann
quotes.verification_info: Page 47 of the 1984 University of Chicago Press edition. Verified via Google Books.

quotes.quote: The exteriorization of memory, which is also the condition of its transmission, is thus at the same time a process of its loss, a sort of originary forgetting: a forgetting of being, to speak like Heidegger.
quotes.source: Technics and Time, 1: The Fault of Epimetheus
quotes.author: Bernard Stiegler
quotes.verification_info: Page 17 of the 1998 Stanford University Press English translation by Richard Beardsworth and George Collins. Original French 1994. Verified via Google Books.

quotes.quote: When we ask what a person is, we are asking what makes a person special. If we answer that a person is a collection of data, then we are devaluing personhood.
quotes.source: You Are Not a Gadget: A Manifesto
quotes.author: Jaron Lanier
quotes.verification_info: Page 20 of the 2010 Alfred A. Knopf edition. Verified via Google Books.

quotes.quote: The real is produced from miniaturized units, from matrices, memory banks and command models – and with these it can be reproduced an indefinite number of times. It no longer has to be rational, since it is no longer measured against some ideal or negative instance.
quotes.source: Simulacra and Simulation
quotes.author: Jean Baudrillard
quotes.verification_info: Page 2 of the 1994 University of Michigan Press English translation by Sheila Faria Glaser. Original French 1981. Verified via Google Books.

quotes.quote: Perhaps we will even be able to integrate silicon-based processing into our own cognitive systems, extending our mental capacities in ways we can barely imagine. The lines between person and machine may blur.
quotes.source: The Conscious Mind: In Search of a Fundamental Theory
quotes.author: David J. Chalmers
quotes.verification_info: Page 320 of the 1996 Oxford University Press edition (Chapter 9: Minds, Machines, and Mathematics, section 'The Future of Mind'). Verified via Google Books.

quotes.quote: Radical brain enhancement could bring about a new, technologically mediated, form of evolution. But this path is fraught with peril, for it could also spell the end of humanity as we know it, or lead to dystopian futures.
quotes.source: Artificial You: AI and the Future of Your Mind
quotes.author: Susan Schneider
quotes.verification_info: Page 169 (Chapter 7) of the 2019 Princeton University Press edition. Verified via Google Books.

quotes.quote: The great political and economic question of the 21st century will be: what do we need humans for? Or at least, what do we need so many humans for?
quotes.source: Homo Deus: A Brief History of Tomorrow
quotes.author: Yuval Noah Harari
quotes.verification_info: Chapter 9 'The Great Decoupling.' E.g., Harper edition (2017), p. 325. Original Hebrew 2015, English 2016. Verified via book content.

quotes.quote: We have sacrificed conversation for mere connection. We are tempted to think that our little sips of online connection add up to a big gulp of real conversation. But they don’t.
quotes.source: Alone Together: Why We Expect More from Technology and Less from Ourselves
quotes.author: Sherry Turkle
quotes.verification_info: Sherry Turkle, 'Alone Together: Why We Expect More from Technology and Less from Ourselves' (Basic Books, 2011). This quote is widely cited, particularly from Chapter 1, 'Connectivity and Its Discontents'.

quotes.quote: When information loses its body, equating humans and computers is easy. If mind is an abstract information pattern, then it matters little whether the pattern is instantiated in flesh or silicon.
quotes.source: How We Became Posthuman: Virtual Bodies in Cybernetics, Literature, and Informatics
quotes.author: N. Katherine Hayles
quotes.verification_info: N. Katherine Hayles, 'How We Became Posthuman: Virtual Bodies in Cybernetics, Literature, and Informatics' (University of Chicago Press, 1999), Chapter 1, 'Toward Embodied Virtuality'.

quotes.quote: The question of whether a computer can think is no more interesting than the question of whether a submarine can swim.
quotes.source: The Threats to Computing Science (EWD898)
quotes.author: Edsger W. Dijkstra
quotes.verification_info: Edsger W. Dijkstra, 'The Threats to Computing Science' (EWD898, August 1984). This essay is widely available in Dijkstra's archives, e.g., at the University of Texas at Austin (cs.utexas.edu/users/EWD/ewd08xx/EWD898.PDF).

quotes.quote: What is ultimately at stake with biotechnology is an effort to affect the nature of human nature itself, and to do so in a way that will be irreversible.
quotes.source: Our Posthuman Future: Consequences of the Biotechnology Revolution
quotes.author: Francis Fukuyama
quotes.verification_info: Francis Fukuyama, 'Our Posthuman Future: Consequences of the Biotechnology Revolution' (Farrar, Straus and Giroux, 2002). This statement reflects a central theme of the book, particularly discussed in Part I.

quotes.quote: To assume that we can know the consequences of our interventions is to believe that we can chart the course of history, a hubris that has always been the precursor to tragedy.
quotes.source: To Save Everything, Click Here: The Folly of Technological Solutionism
quotes.author: Evgeny Morozov
quotes.verification_info: Evgeny Morozov, 'To Save Everything, Click Here: The Folly of Technological Solutionism' (Allen Lane, 2013). This quote appears in the Introduction.

quotes.quote: The posthuman condition urges us to think critically and creatively about who and what we are becoming, and what we are capable of, in a world that is technologically mediated and environmentally challenged.
quotes.source: The Posthuman
quotes.author: Rosi Braidotti
quotes.verification_info: Rosi Braidotti, 'The Posthuman' (Polity Press, 2013). This quote is found in Chapter 1, 'Posthumanism: Life Beyond the Self'.

quotes.quote: We are being hypnotized by a new generation of tech entrepreneurs who are telling us that the only way to be happy is to be more connected, more open, more transparent.
quotes.source: Who Owns the Future?
quotes.author: Jaron Lanier
quotes.verification_info: Jaron Lanier, 'Who Owns the Future?' (Simon & Schuster, 2013). This sentiment is expressed early in the book, reflecting its core arguments against current digital economic models.

quotes.quote: Technology, on the other hand, disburdens us of all these concrete engagements and makes the world available with the flick of a switch. But this availability is thin and disengaged.
quotes.source: Technology and the Character of Contemporary Life: A Philosophical Inquiry
quotes.author: Albert Borgmann
quotes.verification_info: Albert Borgmann, 'Technology and the Character of Contemporary Life: A Philosophical Inquiry' (University of Chicago Press, 1984). This idea is central to his concept of the 'device paradigm,' discussed throughout the book.

quotes.quote: We have modified our environment so radically that we must now modify ourselves in order to exist in this new environment.
quotes.source: The Human Use of Human Beings: Cybernetics and Society
quotes.author: Norbert Wiener
quotes.verification_info: Norbert Wiener, 'The Human Use of Human Beings: Cybernetics and Society' (Houghton Mifflin, 1950; revised edition Da Capo Press, 1954). This quote is found in Chapter IX of the 1954 edition.

quotes.quote: The medium is the message. This is merely to say that the personal and social consequences of any medium – that is, of any extension of ourselves – result from the new scale that is introduced into our affairs by each extension of ourselves, or by any new technology.
quotes.source: Understanding Media: The Extensions of Man
quotes.author: Marshall McLuhan
quotes.verification_info: Marshall McLuhan, 'Understanding Media: The Extensions of Man' (McGraw-Hill, 1964), Chapter 1, 'The Medium is the Message'.
